article.title: GeneLab Database Analyses Suggest Long-Term Impact of Space Radiation on the Cardiovascular System by the Activation of FYN Through Reactive Oxygen Species
funding: GeneLab Project at NASA Ames Research Center
article.abstract: Space radiation has recently been considered a risk factor for astronauts’ cardiac health.

sections.introduction: Long-duration space travel has been associated with a number of human health risk factors, such as space radiation, microgravity, isolation, and hypoxia.
sections.methods: All data used for this manuscript were obtained from GeneLab (genelab.nasa.gov).
sections.results: To study the impact of space radiation on the cardiovascular system we utilized three GeneLab datasets (GLDS-52, -117, and -109).
sections.discussion: For long-term space travel, cardiovascular risk is a major concern to astronauts and is thought to arise from both microgravity effects and exposure to space radiation.

article.insights_summary: This study suggests that space radiation has a long-term impact on the cardiovascular system by activating FYN through reactive oxygen species.
article.acknowledgments: J.M. is grateful to Thomas Berger of the Deutsches Zentrum für Luft-und Raumfahrt (DLR) for providing the dose data from the ESA-Columbus module.
